Article Title: India needs $22tn for net zero by 2070; coal use to rise till 2047: Niti Aayog
Article Text: NEW DELHI: At a time when India is working on its 2035 climate action targets, the govt’s think tank, Niti Aayog, on Monday released a roadmap to achieve the country’s ‘net zero’ emission goal by 2070, noting that the transition will need cumulative investment requirements of $22.7 trillion, around $500 billion annually, to finance several “high-level actions” to meet the twin objectives of ‘Viksit Bharat’ (developed India) and long-term carbon neutrality. It said at least $6 trillion out of the total investment requirement needs to come from external sources.The govt think tank also underlined that India’s coal consumption will continue to rise till 2047, giving enough hint of what India’s updated climate action - Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) - for 2035 would look like.The roadmap - Scenarios Towards ‘Viksit Bharat’ and Net Zero: An Overview - emphasised India’s vision of becoming a developed economy by 2047 and achieving ‘net zero’ emissions by 2070, saying it will require a “delicate balancing act”.“Many of the technologies needed for net zero have yet to reach commercial maturity, while mature low-carbon technologies often demand large up-front investments,” the report said, referring to challenges.Noting a scenario of transition to clean energy in India, the report flagged that the non-fossil fuel power generation (including captive) share is expected to increase from 23% in 2025 to 65% in the current policy scenario and 80% in the ‘net zero’ scenario by 2050.“It is further expected to rise above 80% by 2070 in the current policy scenario, and to 100% in the ‘net zero’ scenario, it said.“The ‘net zero’ strategy is simple – first, electrify energy use. Two, green and clean electricity. Three, control demand through Mission LiFE. Four, focus on circularity and efficiency. Last, cheaper external finance is needed. Clearly stated, India’s coal consumption will go up till 2047 even as energy intensity decreases and efficiency goes up, while meeting ‘net zero’ goals. India can leapfrog to be a global leader in clean technologies. 85% of India of 2047 is yet to be built and can be built to be climate-friendly,” said B.V.R Subrahmanyam, CEO, NITI Aayog, on the occasion of the release of the report.Besides focus on clean energy, the roadmap’s high-level actions for India’s ‘net zero’ transition include focus on circularity, urban mobility, efficient buildings, proper land use, critical minerals, and robust data for monitoring, reporting & verification (MRV) systems as core infrastructure.On financing the transition, it noted that the power sector alone accounts for over half of total needs ($22.7 trillion), reflecting its central role in enabling economy-wide electrification and the expansion of low-carbon generation.“On an annualised basis, this cumulative requirement translates into average flows of approximately $500 billion per year, compared with actual annual investment of around $135 billion in 2024, of which only $70–80 billion currently supports clean energy,” the report said.Of this total, approximately $8 trillion must be front-loaded by 2050, including nearly $5 trillion in the power sector, given the capital-intensive nature of most low-carbon technologies, it added.The think tank noted that the financing gap of $6.5 trillion remains, as an estimated aggregate flow of only $16.2 trillion is expected against the ‘net zero’ scenario investment requirement of $22.7 trillion, and suggested having a "National Green Finance Institution" in the country to take care of the needs.It, at the same time, expressed confidence in India’s approach, saying India’s 'net zero' transition will create a new ‘Indian Development Model’ combining economic vitality, technological leadership, and sustainability. “The pathways India shows will be a lighthouse for the developing world. The Indian Development Model will set the trend for others,” said the think tank.“NITI Aayog has undertaken a comprehensive and rigorous exercise that will serve as a benchmark – a starting point for future discussions on ‘Viksit Bharat’ and ‘net zero’. The reports are a great resource for policymakers and researchers on charting India’s course to these twin objectives,” said V Anantha Nageswaran, Chief Economic Advisor to the government.The report has come out with 11 reports that detail the findings of India’s first government-led, multi-sectoral, integrated study to assess development scenarios that deliver on the Viksit Bharat 2047 while simultaneously reducing net greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to zero by 2070.The study entails a “scenario-based analytic modelling exercise” that integrates economic growth, India’s development priorities, and climate commitments. It has been prepared by 10 inter-ministerial working groups that examined long-term transition scenarios across key domains like macroeconomic aspects of the transition, sectoral low-carbon transition in power, transport, industry, buildings, and agriculture; financing for climate action; critical minerals; R&D and manufacturing; and the social implications of the transition.
Article Summary: Niti aayog released a roadmap to achieve the country’s ‘net zero’ emission goal by 2070. The transition will need $22.7 trillion, around $500 billion annually, to finance several ‘high-level actions’ it said at least $6 trillion out of the total investment requirement needs to come from external sources.

Article Title: What are air taxis and how will they work in India? CII report explains
Article Text: NEW DELHI: A pilot air taxi corridor linking Gurugram, Connaught Place and Jewar International Airport could sharply reduce travel time in the National Capital Region, according to a new report by the Confederation of Indian Industry. The study says Advanced Air Mobility solutions, including Electric Vertical Take Off and Landing aircraft, could help India ease infrastructure bottlenecks by shifting a share of urban travel to low-altitude airspace.The report proposes that air taxis initially operate from rooftops of hospitals and commercial buildings and be deployed for time-sensitive missions such as medical logistics and organ transport. Strategic co-location with hospitals, metro stations and business districts would allow integration with existing transport networks, it said.Citing severe pressure on surface transport, the report argues that Advanced Air Mobility is the logical next step for Indian cities. It suggests setting up a new regulatory body within the Directorate General of Civil Aviation to oversee the rollout of these services.Released by Civil Aviation Minister Rammohan Naidu Kinjarapu, the report outlines a phased plan to safely integrate next-generation air mobility into the aviation ecosystem and address urban congestion.Senior officials including DGCA chief Faiz Ahmed Kidwai and Airports Authority of India chairman Vipin Kumar were present at the launch, along with industry leaders.On infrastructure, the report makes a strong case for rooftop vertiports in major metros. “As India prepares Advanced Air Mobility, rooftop vertiports offer an efficient, scalable, and cost-effective solution, especially in cities like Delhi, Mumbai, and Bengaluru,” it said. With land acquisition for ground-based vertiports proving expensive and slow, rooftops of commercial hubs, hospitals, tech parks and residential towers are seen as a practical alternative using under-utilised real estate.However, regulatory hurdles remain. “Under the current DGCA regulations, routine commercial vertical take-offs and landings from rooftops are not yet permitted, and any future enablement would be subject to the evolution of applicable regulatory frameworks and safety assessments,” the report noted. It proposes a sequenced rollout starting with drone deliveries, followed by medical logistics and organ transport, and later air ambulance services.On funding, the report calls on public financial institutions, including SIDBI, banks and government grant agencies, to create dedicated financing instruments for Advanced Air Mobility. These could include sector-specific infrastructure funds, venture leasing models or credit enhancement facilities to lower investment risk and support long-term capital flows.
Article Summary: A pilot air taxi corridor linking gurugram, connaught place and jewar international airport could sharply reduce travel time in the national capital region. The report proposes that air taxis initially operate from rooftops of hospitals and commercial buildings.

Article Title: 'Tried to aggressively push our farm interests in US trade deal': Piyush Goyal
Article Text:
Piyush Goyal (PTI photo)

'Dairy, Agriculture Protected': Piyush Goyal Outlines 'Historic' US-India Trade Deal, Lauds PM Modi

‘Farmers understand their interests & sensitivities have been protected’

Commerce & industry minister

Piyush Goyal

always has his calendar full with meetings, and the last few weeks have been particularly hectic due to the trade deals with the EU and the US. The minister discussed the details of the US deal with

TOI’s

Sidhartha

while insisting that the agreement will help Indian exporters grow and boost two-way trade. Excerpts:

Is there a sense of relief or a sense of accomplishment?

You, your team and others in govt have been working on this for close to a year now. There were ups and downs. What was the turning point?

Modi govt has been known to be very forthright and blunt. The negotiations saw Peter Navarro, commerce secretary Howard Lutnick, treasury secretary Scott Bessent making very aggressive remarks. There was no response from India. Was it deliberate silence?

So, the two sides were making progress even when there were headlines about things sliding towards a point of no return?

You have earlier said each trade deal stands on its own legs. But sheer timing, within eight days, EU and US deals were finalised. Was the EU deal an elephant in the room as far as the Americans are concerned?

Farmers’ bodies have called for a nationwide protest on Feb 12. Do you see that as a risk to the deal?

You have agreed to review non-tariff barriers on US farm products. Second, DDGS is going to be imported. Will it be at the expense of soybean farmers because it is cheaper?

India’s purchase of Russian oil was one of the things that held up the deal. The US executive order talks abouts India stopping Russian oil purchases, but govt has remained silent on it. Can you throw some light on that?

You have lobbed the ball into MEA’s court on Russian oil. How are you going to protect energy security? In your statement in Parliament you spoke about it.

There is also mention of removing import licensing for ICT products in the joint statement. What exactly is it and, two, are we looking at a more resilient supply chain through this?

Is this review also meant to rebalance trade, some of it is coming from countries which are not seen to be very friendly?

This is the first tranche of the trade deal. What is the road ahead? Will services be part of future talks?

There is an explicit reference to the modifications in commitments in case of changes to the agreed tariff by any of the countries. Does it have to do with Trump’s unpredictable nature?

Do you see the deal lifting the cloud of uncertainty over investments which may have been on hold?

Along with the joint statement, USTR issued a map which showed PoK and Aksai Chin as part of India. Is it just a coincidence?

NEW DELHI: Commerce & industry minister Piyush Goyal said Sunday that the govt has aggressively sought to push the farm sector's interests in the US trade deal, while protecting its sensitivities around dairy and agriculture."We have $30-odd billion of imports. The important thing is we have $55 billion of exports of farm and fish produce. So, we should have an offensive interest, which is what we have focused on simultaneously along with protecting the sensitive sectors," he told TOI in an interview.The deal opens the doors for several products such as tea, coffee, spices and fruits with the US allowing their import at zero reciprocal tariff, while also helping seafood exporters compete favourably as the reciprocal tariff has been slashed to 18%.The minister also said that concern over the import of distillers dried grains with solubles, a feed ingredient that is a by-product of dry-milled ethanol production, is misplaced and that India has only opened a small window. While Goyal refused to disclose details, officials said against domestic animal feed consumption of 500 lakh tonnes, the quota offered to the US is only five lakh tonnes.The minister said the demand had come from the industry itself amid rising livestock population and growing requirement for feed, especially at a time when arable land is shrinking.This was long under negotiation, though not very long by FTA standards. It is very satisfying that the world’s largest democracies are coming closer together, further strengthening the most powerful relationship in the world. The US is already a $30 trillion economy and continues to grow, India, even though $4 trillion today, there is a clear roadmap given by the PM towards Viksit Bharat by 2047, we will grow to a $30-35 trillion economy, which means the delta of opportunity is huge. To be able to grab that opportunity we need to have better markets, open new vistas, attract investments, attract technologies to India. Completing EU and US trade deals in a span of eight days is quite satisfying, in a way reflective of India’s emergence as a confident nation.Trade negotiations are about crystal gazing into the future. Both sides look for the best deal, the important thing is to get the right balance, which is a win-win for both sides. As it gets closer towards completion, creating that right balance is always difficult. You are looking at protecting your sensitivities, the other side is looking at protecting their sensitivities. You are looking at your ability to gain from the agreement as is the other side. The process was a labour of love over the last 10 months. It ended on a very happy note with PM Narendra Modi and President Trump in their call last Monday deciding on closing negotiations with a rate for India, which is the best given to any of our competitors.I don’t think we were stuck on any position. I don’t think there was any acrimony on both sides throughout the negotiations. Everybody has a certain style and it’s important to appreciate that style. So, I don’t think India ever got into any misunderstandings on the trade front. Through the negotiations we kept a very good atmosphere.If you don’t misunderstand me, don’t believe the headlines. It is not for the newspapers alone, it’s for all of us. Very often we oversell our own thinking or over buy our own understanding or philosophy. One must always have the ability to listen to another new viewpoint and keep patience, particularly in trade negotiations as they are a long-drawn affair. You can’t rush things. That’s why I’ve often said never have a deadline for trade negotiations, you’ll make mistakes.It’s just that both happened within a short span of time. We are currently engaged in nearly 12-13 negotiations across the world and concluding them quite rapidly. We’ve concluded the UK, New Zealand, Oman, EU and US. There’s another one on the anvil. It reflects India’s growing confidence, growing understanding of international trade and the power of international trade. Our desire to become a developed nation by 2047 cannot be achieved unless we really look at much larger markets across the world.I don’t think so because farmer bodies also understand that we have kept the sensitivities in agriculture fully protected and excluded areas of high production in India, where we are generally self-sufficient: meat, poultry, rice, wheat, sugar, all dairy items, all GM products, soybean and corn. There’s hardly any item where any farmer can feel threatened. We have seen the import statistics. Right from Congress times, we have been importing soybean oil, tree nuts. We have heard this complaint that we have closed our doors to wines and spirits for no reason.A number of fresh and processed fruits continue to be imported. They are not available in India in sufficient measure. India imports 5.5 lakh tonnes of apples and there are certain items which India needs. We have $30-odd billion of imports. The important thing is we have $55 billion of exports of farm and fish produce. So, we should have an offensive interest, which is what we have focused on simultaneously along with protecting the sensitive sectors. American market has been opened for a large number of products for our farmers at zero reciprocal tariff, be it tea, coffee or spices, bananas, coconut, mangoes, kiwi and papaya. Trade is all about competition, comparative advantage. Now, we have the best comparative advantage. It’s for our businesses, our exporters to get the best and make the best of this wonderful deal.The concern about non-tariff barriers is totally misplaced because neither India nor US has non-tariff barriers. If there is any inadvertent or any difficulty to trade on both sides, we have agreed that we should try and smoothen the edges and speed up the benefits of this wonderful agreement. I see no reason why we should not resolve non-tariff barriers. We’ve done that in every agreement. The US has some of the best standards. India is now emerging as a high-quality producer of goods and provider of services. So, we have nothing to fear. As regards DDGS, we have a huge requirement, and it is growing. What we have agreed to is a very small quota. The animal husbandry department and industry desperately wants more DDGS because it’s a very high-quality protein. We have 194 million cattle, 112 million buffaloes and 878 million total livestock. As a govt, I have to balance all interests. But I can assure you we have protected soybeans. We are already importing $5 billion of soybean oil every year. If something was opened by UPA, let’s say for Indonesia or Japan or South Korea or Vietnam, I would rather have more competition as it gets me better price and better quality.Commerce ministry does not deal with this subject. I’m not aware of the details, another ministry deals with this.I did, but based on inputs that MEA gave me.n India needs huge quantities of ICT products for its growth and for engaging with modern technology. In the budget we announced huge concessions for data centres. But if we don’t get Nvidia chips or we don’t get AI equipment or quantum computing equipment or if we are dependent only on other geographies, we are harming our country. This was an offensive interest.India will look to get the best from around the world and at the best prices. In all of that we want to have trusted partners. Our focus is to encourage trade with trusted partners.We will first convert this into a proper agreement and legally binding agreement and thereafter we will continue to see other areas to expand trade and mutual cooperation.No. It is a general clause to make sure that the equitable agreement that we have reached continues to remain equitable.I certainly see this as a big boost for investments given that investors like predictability and stability and they love to see a strong relationship on the trade front. They can now plan investments with the confidence that import duty on their inputs are all very clear.Again, this is not my subject.
Article Summary: 'dairy, agriculture protected': piyush goyal outlines 'historic' us-india trade deal, lauds pm modi. Goyal insists that the agreement will help indian exporters grow and boost two-way trade. Goyal refused to disclose details, officials said against domestic animal feed consumption of 500 lakh tonnes, the quota offered to the us is only five lakh tonnes.

Article Title: PSLV-C62 Mishap: Failure analysis committee to be formed soon
Article Text:
Third Stage Trouble Strikes Again: Inside ISRO’s PSLV-C62 Deviation And What The Failure Means Ahead

BENGALURU: Isro, which has been analysing the data from the failed PSLV-C62 from Jan 12, is expected to formally constitute a Failure Analysis Committee (FAC) to investigate the causes for the mishap and recommend corrective measures soon.It has been nearly a month since the failure, the second for PSLV in as many attempts, and so far, the analysis has been done by an expert committee that is being called “data analysis committee” or DAC internally, multiple sources confirmed to TOI.Isro chairman V Narayanan told TOI: “The expert committee is analysing the data,” without elaborating further. The DAC’s task, one scientist said, was to analyse telemetry, ground station records, log books and process documents, and place them on a single timeline before any higher-level inquiry begins.To do this, another scientist said that the DAC has about around six minutes of flight information, recorded at intervals as fine as two milliseconds. He described this as a large amount of material that could reveal the health of the vehicle up to the moment of the anomaly.Isro has not indicated a timeline for the next PSLV launch — built by the HAL-L&T consortium — which was initially expected in the first quarter of this calendar year.Multiple sources confirmed that the mission has been put on hold until the analysis of the PSLV-C62 failure is complete.“The committee [DAC] is in the final leg of its analysis and once it completes the process, the FAC will be formally set up. This could happen very soon, in just a few days,” one source said. Unlike the DAC, which is being headed for a former Isro chairman and comprises internal teams, the FAC will comprise experts from outside the Department of Space (DoS) too.Aside from analysing the data from the PSLV-C62 mission to determine what exactly occurred during the mission, the DAC’s second priority, the scientist said, was to check for any link with the previous failure (PSLV-C61 from May 2025), followed by a complete review of the 33-year-old PSLV vehicle.“Having two repeated failures, it is essential to revisit the entire PSLV once again,” the scientist said. He added that the role of the DAC was to provide all the information that the FAC may require to carry out its analysis.“There will be data from telemetry, ground station, tracking data, other information about processes and tests, all of which need to be analysed and presented properly for the FAC to begin work,” the scientist said.While Isro has not formally said that the launches of other launch vehicles, the agency has been carrying out stringent reviews ahead of all planned missions. As reported by TOI last week, it is gearing up for a GSLV mission, while the planned SSLV mission is said to be put on hold given that its second stage is the same as the PSLV’s third stage (PS3).On Jan 12, after a normal lift-off and second stage performance, the PSLV-C62 suffered a glitch in PS3, which led to the failure. “...Close to the end of the third stage, we saw little more disturbance in the vehicle roll rates and subsequently there was a deviation in the flight path. We are analysing the data and we shall come back at the earliest,” Narayanan had said soon after.
Article Summary: Isro expected to formally constitute a failure analysis committee (fac) to investigate the causes for the mishap and recommend corrective measures soon. The analysis has been done by an expert committee that is being called “data analysis committee” or dac internally, multiple sources confirmed to toi.

Article Title: Two decades of sat data show gradual dip in Uttarakhand hills green cover
Article Text: BENGALURU: Satellites watching the sweep of the Himalayas have begun to read the mountains like a slow-moving diary. Grasslands revive with the seasons, forests deepen in colour, and valley flora shifts its pattern, yet the same images also carry warnings of strain. An analysis of two-decade data of Uttarakhand’s vegetation shows how closely the region responds to climate and how those rhythms are starting to falter.Mountain ecosystems react faster than most landscapes to changes in temperature and rainfall. Rising global surface temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are already influencing plant growth, soil moisture, and snow cover. Scientists say this makes local and long-term monitoring essential if govts are to prepare for floods, droughts, and biodiversity loss.To track these changes, researchers from the Aryabhatta Research Institute of Observational Sciences (ARIES) in Nainital, an autonomous institute under the department of science and technology (DST), worked with Indian and international collaborators using Google Earth Engine, or GEE, a platform that processes large volumes of satellite data.The tool allows scientists to study land degradation, urban growth, dust movement, and temperature trends without the heavy burden of storing raw images.The team examined satellite records from 2001 to 2022 and relied on a widely used indicator called the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). The index measures how plants reflect light and provides a simple guide to their health. Low NDVI values point to rock, sand, water, or snow, while higher values signal dense forests, croplands, or wetlands. The researchers also studied the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI), which performs better in areas with thick biomass.Their findings of the study led by Umesh Dumka from ARIES, published in the journal “Environmental Monitoring and Assessment”, reveal clear seasonal cycles. NDVI and EVI peak after the monsoon when hills turn lush, and fall to their lowest levels before the rains. Monthly and yearly variations follow a familiar pattern, yet the long-term graphs show a gradual decline.The study links this drop to deforestation, expanding agriculture, illegal logging, and rising pollution from towns and industries. Pollution, the researchers note, does not strike evenly. Some pockets suffer heavier damage, adding to the stress created by warming temperatures and erratic rainfall. Such pressures threaten wildlife habitats, river systems, and the livelihoods of millions who depend on the mountains downstream.Using time-series maps generated through GEE, the scientists compared vegetation trends with climate data and applied Pearson’s correlation to understand their relationship. The approach allowed them to pinpoint districts where greenery has weakened most sharply.The authors argue that satellite science can serve as an early-warning system. By identifying vulnerable zones, authorities can plan afforestation, regulate construction, and control emissions before losses become irreversible. The Himalayas, they say, are signalling distress in a language of pixels and numbers. Listening to that message may decide how resilient the region remains in the decades ahead.
Article Summary: Mountain ecosystems react faster than most landscapes to changes in temperature and rainfall. Rising global surface temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are already influencing plant growth, soil moisture, and snow cover. Scientists say this makes local and long-term monitoring essential if govts are to prepare for floods, droughts, and biodiversity loss.

Article Title: Instead of foreign data, ICMR wants India’s own evidence to treat lifestyle diseases
Article Text:
.

NEW DELHI: In a shift aimed at making medical treatment more relevant to Indian patients, the Indian Council of Medical Research has called for large, multi-centre clinical trials to generate India-specific evidence for treating lifestyle and chronic diseases, instead of relying largely on data from Western countries.The move targets conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, cancer and other non-communicable diseases that affect millions across the country. Health experts say therapies proven effective in Western populations do not always produce the same results in Indian patients because of differences in genetics, diet, climate, disease patterns and access to care.The need for such an approach is already evident in ongoing research. Dr Ambuj Rao, cardiologist at AIIMS Delhi, said India-specific clinical research is essential, pointing to a pan-India influenza vaccine trial in heart attack patients currently underway at AIIMS. He noted that evidence for such interventions cannot come from Western countries because India has a distinct flu season and different public health challenges.Under the initiative, networks of at least five hospitals will jointly evaluate treatments, medical procedures, digital tools and lifestyle interventions in real-world Indian settings.The aim is to identify therapies that are not only clinically effective but also affordable and workable within government hospitals and public health programmes. Officials said the findings will directly inform national treatment guidelines, with each selected study eligible for funding of up to Rs 8 crore over four years.Dr Ravinder Goswami from the endocrinology department at AIIMS Delhi said India’s tropical climate, repeated cycles of stress and poverty, and distinct dietary patterns have led to unique metabolic and hormonal adaptations in Indians, including insulin resistance, higher cortisol levels, central obesity and lower muscle mass. He said rapid lifestyle changes and the growing consumption of refined foods have worsened the burden of diabetes, hypertension, polycystic disorders and other metabolic diseases, which require culturally acceptable and India-specific treatment strategies. The ICMR’s call for well-planned studies, he added, offers a crucial opportunity to generate evidence for conditions unique to India, including certain metabolic disorders and cancers such as oral cancer.Beyond improving treatment protocols, the programme is also expected to strengthen India’s research capacity. Participating hospitals will be required to conduct trials independently, maintain standardised digital records and share data transparently, reducing dependence on pharmaceutical-driven global research.Public health experts say the initiative could have a direct impact on patients, as even small changes in treatment protocols, backed by Indian evidence, can improve outcomes and reduce out-of-pocket spending for families living with chronic disease. If successful, the effort could ensure that what doctors prescribe in India is guided by data generated from Indian patients, not assumptions imported from elsewhere.
Article Summary: The indian council of medical research has called for large, multi-centre clinical trials to generate india-specific evidence. The move targets conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, cancer and other non-communicable diseases. Health experts say therapies proven effective in western populations do not always produce the same results in indian patients.

Article Title: Bank holidays in February 2026: When and where will banks remain closed — Check state-wise list
Article Text:
When and where are banks closed in February 2026?

February 18:

February 19:

February 20:

Planning to visit a bank in February? It’s smart to check the holiday schedule first, as an unexpected closure can turn a quick errand into a wasted trip. In India, banks observe both national and state-specific holidays, so closure dates may differ from one region to another. In India, bank holidays include both national and state-specific observances, so closure dates can vary across different regions.Banks will remain closed in Sikkim on account of the Losar festival.Banks will be closed in Maharashtra for Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Jayanti.Banks will not operate in Mizoram and Arunachal Pradesh in observance of State Day/Statehood Day.Apart from these, banks will also remain closed on second and fourth Saturdays of the month, according to RBI.Being aware of bank holidays in advance can help customers plan essential financial transactions and avoid last-minute hassles. While branches may remain closed on these days, it does not prevent customers from carrying out routine transactions. Digital banking services, including online banking, ATMs, mobile apps, and UPI, remain fully operational for fund transfers, bill payments, and other regular activities.However, services that require a physical visit such as large cash deposits, cheque clearances, or issuing demand drafts will not be available. To prevent inconvenience, account holders are encouraged to plan these tasks ahead and make full use of digital banking options during closures.
Article Summary: Banks will be closed in maharashtra for chhatrapati shivaji maharaj jayanti. Services that require a physical visit such as large cash deposits, cheque clearances, or issuing demand drafts will not be available. Digital banking services, including online banking, atms, mobile apps, and upi, remain fully operational.

Article Title: IT stocks crash! Rs 2.5 lakh crore erased in 3 Days — What should investors do?
Article Text:
Anthropic unveiled new automation tools

Palantir's announcement that its AI platform can now complete SAP migrations in weeks rather than the years traditionally required.

What's the outlook?



IT stock investors are struggling with sharp losses as the sector is going through a phase of massive sell offs. In the past three trading sessions, Nifty IT index has plunged almost 8%, erroding almost Rs 2.5 lakh crore from the market value. Traders are also concerned about concerns over AI automation, that could majorly disrupt the traditional outsourcing model.The recent market turbulence arose from two key developments:The latter claim rattled investors, as ERP implementation was previously considered largely immune to AI disruption. Motilal Oswal’s Abhishek Pathak offered a stark assessment of the potential impact. “Assuming a 30–50% productivity hit on low-level work in these areas, we believe 9–12% of IT services revenue stands to be eliminated. We expect this to happen over three to four years, underscoring a ~2% hit on revenue growth each year,” he told ET. He noted that before Palantir’s comments, 30–40% of IT services revenues were already thought to be at risk from AI deflation, particularly in application development, maintenance, and testing.Pathak warned that the scope of AI’s disruption could expand. “If ERP migration and third-party enterprise software, which accounts for 10–15% of industry revenues, come under the purview of AI, the hit from AI would be higher,” he said.The selloff intensified after Palantir’s earnings call highlighted AI’s potential in areas that were once considered safe haven. “The key catalyst was the Palantir earnings call, which highlighted how the company is upending pay-per-seat software such as Workday and ServiceNow, as well as third-party software with its own AI offerings,” Pathak said.Additional factors weighed on sentiment. “Anthropic’s entry into automating low-level legal services work and Gartner’s muted guidance also had a bearing on sentiment,” Pathak added. “While AI’s threat to software coding hours was well known, Palantir’s comments put ERP implementation into the spotlight, which so far was considered less impacted by AI’s productivity gains.”Historical experience suggests that such disruption, while challenging, can ultimately benefit the industry. “AI will render much of legacy software and testing redundant. Just like hyperscalers were initially a significant headwind to infrastructure management services, and BPO got disrupted in an earlier cycle in 2015,” Pathak noted. “Many legacy IMS and BPO roles do not exist anymore, but cloud migration over a five-year period proved accretive for the industry. ”He added that the transition period can be bumpy. “During the early cloud build-out phase in 2016–17, hyperscaler capex expansion initially acted as a revenue headwind for Indian IT services as enterprises paused traditional outsourcing in favour of direct cloud investments. Once the capex cycle normalised, industry growth re-accelerated sharply.”Some analysts, however, see a more positive outlook for IT services compared with software firms. BofA Securities’ Amish Shah explained, “We think that the plug-ins being released by AI companies matter more for the software companies and do not change much for the IT services companies. The broader developments around AI’s use in business have been moving more constructively over the past few months. Companies have been highlighting the increasing opportunity available for them as more AI pilots go into an implementation phase and that their partnership with AI-first companies is driving up demand for enterprise-grade AI solutions. ”Shah also acknowledged emerging concerns. “There has been associated news flow that claims AI tools are helping finish SAP migration in a few weeks versus taking a few years earlier. This has become a new topic of discussion around deflation risk levels in the IT services sector.”From a technical standpoint, the Nifty IT index is at a crucial level, holding 35,400 on a closing basis. “However, a breakdown below this level could potentially create mayhem in the sector,” said Rupak De, Senior Technical Analyst at LKP Securities. “On the other hand, if the index sustains above 35,400, we can expect a meaningful price recovery in the IT space.”With large-cap IT stocks trading at around 20 times one-year forward earnings, slightly below their 10-year average, Shah recommended caution. “We would continue to maintain a selective stance on the sector and prefer only those companies where visibility of acceleration in growth in FY27 is high, backed by their ability to participate in AI services spends and where there is a proactive and concerted push towards an AI-led operating model,” he told ET.Unmesh Sharma of HDFC Securities offered a balanced view, “We have a neutral position on Indian IT companies in our model portfolio and we continue to hold that." The expert added that although India may not lead in AI innovation, Indian companies are expected to play a significant role in implementing AI solutions across the corporate sector.
Article Summary: In the past three trading sessions, nifty it index has plunged almost 8%, erroding almost rs 2.5 lakh crore from the market value. Traders are also concerned about concerns over ai automation, that could majorly disrupt the traditional outsourcing model.

Article Title: Scent of Ramadan 2026: Gulf's top Arabic cologne trends for women
Article Text:
Ramadan 2026 Fragrance Trends: Arabic Perfumes for Women, Floral-Oriental and Amber Scents

Floral-oriental elegance in Ramadan 2026 for femininity with depth



Warm spices and amber for richness during Ramadan 2026 nights



Ramadan's Scented Secrets: Are Women's Fragrance Choices Becoming Too Bold?

Soft sweetness and powdered accords during Ramadan 2026 for versatility and grace

Layerable and sensory experiences in Ramadan 2026 for personal scent journeys

What Fragrances Will Define Ramadan 2026 for Women? Exploring Arabic Perfume Trends

Why Arabic perfume culture is resonating with women ahead of Ramadan 2026







As the holy month of Ramadan gears up to unfold across the Middle East and beyond, women’s fragrance choices are becoming a meaningful expression of personal style, cultural resonance and sensory storytelling. Arabic perfumes, long celebrated for their rich, evocative compositions, are trending this season not just as gifts or evening scents but as symbolic extensions of the Ramadan experience: warm, comforting and deeply memorable.In 2026, the narrative around women’s fragrances reflects broader industry shifts toward textural sophistication and emotional connection. Global perfumery trends emphasise personalisation, immersive scent experiences and nuanced reinterpretations of classic notes, all of which align beautifully with the rich palette of Arabic perfumery.One of the defining movements in the Ramadan perfume landscape this year is the resurgence of floral-oriental compositions. These perfumes blend soft blossoms like jasmine and rose with deeper bases such as amber and musk, resulting in scents that feel both romantic and sophisticated. For many women, these fragrances strike the perfect balance between everyday elegance and evening allure, suitable for mosque visits, iftar gatherings or Eid celebrations.Floral-oriental profiles are evolving in 2026 to feel more refined and textured. Industry voices note that florals are being paired with unexpected elements of earthier woods, nuanced resins or gourmand undertones, giving traditional blooms a modern and personal expression.As the sun sets and social rhythms begin, many women are drawn toward warm spice and amber compositions. These fragrances open with rich, comforting top notes, often complemented by subtle hints of spice, before settling into amber-clad bases that envelop the wearer in warmth. These profiles are especially beloved for evening wear, when gatherings with loved ones call for something both bold and memorable.In a broader context, amber and spice-driven perfumes resonate with a growing preference for scents that feel like a sensory hug: enveloping, rich and long-lasting. This mirrors global trends where gourmands and amber accords are gaining traction for their comforting, tactile qualities.Another strong current in the Ramadan fragrance story for women is the rise of softly sweet and powdery scents. These are lighter, more approachable compositions featuring gentle sweetness or subtle vanilla-like nuances layered with musky or floral undertones.They are excellent for daytime moments of quiet reflection, casual outings or workplaces where subtlety and elegance are valued over bold projection. This trend toward nuanced sweetness also reflects a shift in the industry where refined gourmand notes feel less dessert-sweet and more textured, mature and wearable.More women are also embracing the idea of scent layering by combining multiple fragrances or formats (like concentrated oils, sprays or body mists) to create something uniquely personal. This approach echoes a broader 2026 trend toward “scent wardrobes” or narrative fragrance experiences, where a perfume isn’t just a single choice but part of a richer sensory identity.Layering allows for playful contrasts like a soft floral with a warm amber base or a light citrus top with a spice-accented dry-down, offering versatility throughout the varied moments of Ramadan and Eid.Arabic perfumes for women this Ramadan are not just trending because of their notes; they are resonating because they bridge tradition and contemporary expression. Their richness and depth reflect cultural heritage, while their evolving compositions align with global fragrance innovations, from gumptious amber blends to nuanced floral artistry.Whether worn for spiritual reflection, family gatherings or festive evenings, these fragrances are helping redefine how scent plays into holiday rituals, turning each application into a small celebration of identity, memory and beauty.
Article Summary: Ramadan 2026 fragrance trends: arabic perfumes for women, floral-oriental and amber scents. Women’s fragrance choices are becoming a meaningful expression of personal style, cultural resonance and sensory storytelling. Arabic perfumes are trending this season not just as gifts or evening scents but as symbolic extensions of the ramadan experience.

Article Title: “He hated it”: Travis Kelce reportedly felt awkward and forced during outings with Taylor Swift’s former friends Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds
Article Text:
Travis Kelce reportedly felt awkward and forced during outings with Taylor Swift’s former friend Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds.(Image via Getty Images, Ryan Reynolds/Instagram)

Travis Kelce reportedly never liked hanging out with Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds when Taylor Swift was friends with them

Travis Kelce seems to be worried about Taylor Swift

Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce publicly distanced themselves from the pop star’s former best friend, Blake Lively, and her husband, popular Hollywood actor, Ryan Reynolds, ever since their legal drama with Justin Baldoni began.While Taylor Swift could be called to court after her controversial text exchange with Blake Lively was made public, it seems Travis Kelce was never fond of their company.A few hours ago, as per Rob Shuter, a source revealed that, “He hated the double-dating…He felt like it was all optics and no authenticity.”The source added, “Travis is blunt and real…Ryan is curated. That contrast never worked.”Just two months before Taylor Swift was dragged in the legal chaos between Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni, the pop star and Travis Kelce were spotted on a double date with the Hollywood power couple.That was the last time either Taylor Swift or Travis Kelce were spotted alongside Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds. The two have remained publicly distant from the Hollywood power couple ever since.Around a year ago, there were also strong speculations of Travis Kelce removing Ryan Reynolds from his social media.But neither Travis Kelce nor Ryan Reynolds addressed the speculations in public.While Taylor Swift remains private about her emotions about the situation, it seems Travis Kelce is pretty concerned about her and his future in the league after a pretty poor season on the field.According to The U.S. Sun, a source has said, "Between a difficult season, the reality of preparing for retirement—which has left him stressed and a bit depressed…”The insider added, “And the looming possibility of Taylor being called to court as a witness, it's been emotionally exhausting and increasingly frustrating for him to handle."This has also led to many insiders claiming that Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce have decided to put their “wedding on hold” until they are able to deal with the issues in their lives.However, both Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce have stayed away from confirming these speculations in public.
Article Summary: Travis kelce reportedly felt awkward and forced during outings with taylor swift’s former friend blake lively and ryan reynolds. The two have remained publicly distant from the hollywood power couple ever since. Taylor swift and travis kelce have stayed away from confirming these speculations in public.

Article Title: Marc Cucurella and Claudia Rodriguez combined net worth: How the Chelsea star built his fortune along with luxury lifestyle
Article Text:
Marc Cucurella and Claudia Rodriguez (Image Source: Getty)

Marc Cucurella’s steps in forming his fortune and football career progression

Claudia Rodríguez’s role, lifestyle, income streams, and combined worth of the couple

The financial status of Marc Cucurella and Claudia Rodríguez demonstrates how Cucurella achieved success in professional football while Rodríguez built her career in communications and media. The financial earnings of Cucurella come from his contracts, bonuses and endorsement deals, while Rodríguez generates income through her professional work and expanding social media presence.The couple maintains a balanced relationship, which enables them to achieve both athletic accomplishments and media-driven branding success, which supports their ability to live a lifestyle that includes expensive travel, designer clothing and family-oriented activities. The couple established themselves as one of football's most respected young couples through their combination of work accomplishments and personal happiness.Marc Cucurella has built his wealth through his gradual advancement in professional football. He began his career at Barcelona's renowned academy but later transferred to Getafe before joining Brighton, and finally, Chelsea acquired him through a £62 million transfer in 2022.The Chelsea contract he signed runs through 2028 and offers him an impressive financial package.His international competition for Spain at the senior level has increased his market value through performance bonuses. Marc Cucurella has several endorsement deals, contracts that increase his value apart from the sports he plays. These contracts are a result of the endorsement of sportswear and lifestyle brands. His career accomplishments are depicted through his lifestyle that includes luxurious cars and homes.Claudia Rodríguez has established herself in communications and media while also being active on Instagram, where she keeps sharing glimpses of family life, fashion, and travel. Through her social media presence, she establishes her personal brand while generating additional revenue streams. The couple builds their combined wealth through their professional work and social media presence, which also determines their shared way of life. They share family time with their children through vacations while enjoying a relaxed home environment.Chelsea defender Marc Cucurella and his partner, Claudia Rodríguez, are estimated to have a net worth of $15- $18 million.
Article Summary: Chelsea defender marc cucurella and his partner, claudia rodríguez, are estimated to have a net worth of $15- $18 million. The couple established themselves as one of football's most respected young couples through their combination of work accomplishments and personal happiness.

Article Title: Samsung Galaxy F70e with 6,000 mAh battery, 50MP camera launched in India: Price, specs and more
Article Text:
Samsung Galaxy F70e: Price and availability



Samsung Galaxy F70e specifications



Samsung Galaxy F70e is now official. Samsung has expanded its Galaxy F-series of smartphones with the launch of Galaxy F70e in India. The smartphone features a 50MO main camera and comes with a dedicated Night Mode for brighter and detailed pictures. Samsung Galaxy F70e also features an HD+ display and has a leather pattern finish at the back. The smartphone also comes with IP54 rating which makes water and dust-resistant. The smartphone packs a MediaTek chipset and houses a 6,000 mAh battery.Samsung Galaxy F70e comes in two variants — 4GB+128GB and 6GB+128GB priced at Rs 12,999 and Rs 14,999 respectively. The smartphone will be available online on Flipkart and Samsung.com and offline on authorised retail stores in the country starting February 17. Samsung has also announced limited period bank discount which brings down the price to Rs 11,999.Samsung Galaxy F70e features a 6.7-inch HD+ display with 720x1600 pixel resolution. The display offers up to 800 nits of peak brightness level. The smartphone is powered by an octa-core MediaTek Dimensity 6300 chipset. The smartphone comes in two variants — 4GB+128GB and 6GB+128GB. Users can further expand the storage by adding a microSD card of up to 1TB.The dual SIM Samsung smartphone houses a 50MP main camera with f/1.8 aperture and 2MP depth sensor. Front is home to an 8MP selfie camera with f/2.0 aperture.Samsung Galaxy F70e comes equipped with a side-mounted fingerprint sensor and is backed by a 6,000 mAh battery with 25W fast charging support. The company claims that the battery lasts for up to two days on a single charge.Additionally, its Samsung Knox Vault—which protects users’ financial and personal data from any kind of malware & hardware attack—is Evaluation Assurance Level 5+ (EAL5+) certified. This indicates that its security features have undergone rigorous testing and evaluation, especially for applications in finance, healthcare, and critical infrastructure.
Article Summary: Samsung has expanded its galaxy f-series of smartphones with the launch of galaxy f70e in india. The smartphone features a 50mo main camera and comes with a dedicated night mode for brighter and detailed pictures. It also features an hd+ display and has a leather pattern finish at the back.

Article Title: Apple iPhone 17e reportedly coming soon: A19 chip, MagSafe charging and other features expected
Article Text:
Apple iPhone 17e features (expected)

Apple iPhone 17e price (expected)

Apple is reportedly gearing up to announce the successor to last year’s iPhone 16e. Likely to be called iPhone 17e, the smartphone “is due imminently”, claims Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman in the latest edition of his weekly PowerOn newsletter. “Apple will market the 17e heavily to users in emerging economies and enterprises — two areas the company plans to target aggressively this year with both devices and software,” Gurman writes in the newsletter. He also shared that the phone will come with a few “big changes” that include iPhone 17’s A19 chipset and MagSafe charging, among others.The upcoming iPhone 17e, Gurman says will be powered by the A19 chip that comes with iPhone 17. The A19 offers a modest boost in CPU speed compared to the A18, but most of its improvement is in GPU, thus allowing it to be even better for AI features and gaming.Further, the handset is tipped to get MagSafe charging feature. Another change coming the iPhone 17e is that it may be equipped with Apple’s newest in-house cellular and wireless chips.Korean news outlet The Elec previously reported that the iPhone 17e is expected to feature slimmer display bezels while retaining the iPhone 14-era OLED panel. Other major new features include an 18MP front camera with Center Stage. This camera automatically extends to show everybody in a group selfie, even when you hold the phone vertically.As far as the pricing of the upcoming iPhone 17e is concerned, Gurman says that the company is planning to keep pricing the same as iPhone 16e. To recall, iPhone 16e launched in 2025 with a price tag of $599 or Rs 59,900 in India.
Article Summary: Apple is reportedly gearing up to announce the successor to last year’s iphone 16e. Likely to be called iphone 17e, the smartphone ‘is due imminently’ the phone will come with a few ‘big changes’ that include iphone 17”s a19 chipset and magsafe charging, among others.

Senior citizens seeking smartphones in 2026 can choose from multiple options that prioritise ease of use and accessibility. These phones deliver a user-friendly experience with features designed for older adults who want to stay connected with family and friends. Whether you are looking for a smartphone with a large, easy-to-read display, loud and clear audio for better call quality, or extended battery life to reduce charging frequency, brands such as Apple Google , and others offer a range of options. Before finalising your purchase, here is some advice on what to look for in a smartphone for senior citizens:While choosing a smartphone for senior citizens, several factors make the experience more comfortable and accessible. A large display with adjustable font sizes is essential for reading messages, contacts, and menus without strain. Loud, clear audio and hearing-aid compatibility improve call quality and ensure conversations are easy to follow. Long battery life reduces the hassle of frequent charging, which can be inconvenient for older adults. Additional features such as simplified user interfaces, emergency calling options, and accessibility settings for vision and hearing can further enhance the experience. Here’s a curated list of phones expected to deliver a comfortable experience in 2026:Apple's iPhone 17 brings the company's renowned ease of use and accessibility features to a more affordable price point than the Pro models.The device runs iOS 26 with Apple Intelligence and comprehensive accessibility options, making it particularly suitable for senior users.The iPhone 17 features a 6.3-inch ProMotion display with 120Hz refresh rate and a record-high 3,000 nits brightness, making it easy to read in all lighting conditions. The display can be customised with larger text sizes and bold fonts through iOS accessibility settings. The thinner borders provide more screen real estate for content while maintaining a comfortable grip.iOS offers extensive accessibility features, including the VoiceOver screen reader, Display & Text Size adjustments, Spoken Content, and Audio Descriptions. The phone supports Made for iPhone hearing aids and includes features such as Live Captions and Sound Recognition that alert users to important sounds, such as doorbells or alarms.For the first time, all iPhone 17 models feature 48MP Fusion cameras with both wide and ultra-wide lenses. The new 18MP Centre Stage front camera automatically keeps users in frame during FaceTime and WhatsApp video calls, making it easier to stay connected with family. The camera works in both portrait and landscape orientations.The A19 chip delivers smooth performance for everyday tasks like messaging, browsing, and video calls. The improved battery provides up to 30 hours of video playback. The phone features Ceramic Shield 2 protection on both front and back, offering 3–4x better scratch and crack resistance than previous models.Apple's N1 wireless chip provides improved Wi-Fi 7 and Bluetooth 6 connectivity. The eSIM-only design means no physical SIM card management. The phone comes with seven years of software updates, ensuring long-term security and access to new features.Google has positioned the Pixel 9a as an accessible smartphone with excellent camera capabilities and a clean software experience. The device is powered by the Tensor G4 chip and runs Android 15 with seven years of software and security updates.The Google Pixel 9a features a 6.3-inch Actua display with a 120Hz refresh rate and 2,700 nits peak brightness, ensuring excellent visibility in bright sunlight. The display size strikes a balance between readability and one-handed use. Android's accessibility features include the TalkBack screen reader, Live Caption for all media, and Live Transcribe for real-time transcription of conversations.The redesigned build features IP68 water- and dust-resistance, protecting the phone from accidental spills and splashes. The phone includes biometric security options and a simplified setup process to make it easier for first-time smartphone users.On the camera front, the Pixel 9a features a dual-camera system with a 48MP main camera and a 13MP ultrawide lens. The 13MP front camera supports clear video calls with family and friends. The phone introduces Macro Focus to the A-series and includes AI-powered computational photography features like Add Me, Best Take, Magic Editor, Night Sight, and Magic Eraser that simplify photo editing.The device is equipped with a 5,100mAh battery that supports both wired (23W) and wireless charging, providing all-day battery life for typical senior use, including calls, messaging, and occasional browsing. The Tensor G4 chip with 8GB RAM ensures smooth performance for everyday tasks.Connectivity options include 5G, Wi-Fi 6E, Bluetooth 5.3, and NFC. The phone includes Google's suite of services and family-focused features, making it easy to share photos, calendars, and location with loved ones.Samsung has expanded its Galaxy A-series with the Galaxy A17, a reliable mid-range smartphone that offers "Easy Mode" support for a simplified user interface. The smartphone packs an Exynos chipset and features an FHD+ display, making it an excellent balance of features and simplicity.The Samsung Galaxy A17 features a 6.7-inch FHD+ display with 1080x2340 pixel resolution and a 90 Hz refresh rate, providing smooth scrolling and comfortable viewing. The display is protected with Corning Gorilla Glass Victus. The large screen is ideal for seniors who want to read messages, browse the web, or watch videos without eye strain.Samsung's One UI offers Easy Mode, which simplifies the home screen with larger icons, bigger fonts, and a streamlined layout. The interface reduces complexity and makes essential functions more accessible. The phone includes Samsung's accessibility features, such as Voice Assistant, magnification gestures, and high-contrast fonts.The smartphone is powered by an octa-core Exynos 1330 chipset paired with up to 8GB RAM, providing adequate performance for everyday tasks. Storage options include 128GB and 256GB variants, with microSD card support up to 2TB for additional space.The Galaxy A17 sports a 50MP main camera, a 5MP ultra-wide-angle lens, and a 2MP macro camera. The 13MP front camera delivers clear selfies and video calls. The camera app includes simplified shooting modes that make photography straightforward.The smartphone is equipped with a 5,000mAh battery and 25W fast charging, ensuring all-day battery life. The IP54 rating provides resistance to dust and water, while the side-mounted fingerprint sensor offers convenient security. The phone runs Android 15 with Samsung's One UI layer.The Realme C61 is an affordable smartphone designed for durability and simplicity. The device features an integrated metallic frame and is TUV Rheinland-certified, with ArmorShell protection.The smartphone features a large display that makes it easy to read messages and navigate menus. The circular-shaped front camera cutout is minimally intrusive, maximising screen space for content. Realme's custom Android 14-based UI offers a clean interface suitable for first-time smartphone users.The Realme C61 features IP54 dust and water resistance, protecting the phone from everyday accidents and light splashes. The rear dual-camera system provides basic photography capabilities for capturing family moments and sharing photos.The device is powered by a UNISOC Speedtrum T612 processor, paired with up to 4GB of RAM and up to 128GB of internal storage. The 5,000 mAh battery capacity ensures the phone can last a full day or more on a single charge, reducing charging frequency. The phone supports 45W charging for quick top-ups when needed.The Realme C61 offers good value with its clear display, long battery life, and durable build quality, making it suitable for seniors who want a reliable smartphone at an affordable price point without complex features.Xiaomi has expanded its entry-level smartphone lineup with the Redmi A5, designed for first-time smartphone users. The smartphone features a large HD+ display and runs Android 15, with 2 years of OS updates and 4 years of security patches.The Redmi A5 features a 6.88-inch HD+ display with a 720x1680-pixel resolution and up to a 120Hz refresh rate, providing smooth scrolling for comfortable browsing. The large screen makes text and icons easy to see. The display includes TÜV Rheinland-certified eye protection, reducing strain during extended use.The smartphone is powered by an octa-core Unisoc T7250 chipset and up to 4GB of RAM. Storage options include 64GB and 128GB, expandable up to 2TB via microSD card. This provides ample space for photos, videos, and apps without worrying about storage limits.The affordable Redmi smartphone features a 32MP rear camera with an f/2.0 aperture for capturing clear photos in good lighting, along with a secondary camera. The 8MP front camera supports video calls with family members. The simple camera interface makes photography straightforward.The Redmi A5 is backed by a 5,200mAh battery with 15W charging support, ensuring the phone can comfortably last through a day or more of typical usage. The side-mounted fingerprint sensor enables convenient, secure unlocking.The phone is available in Pondicherry Blue, Just Black, and Lake Green. With its simple Android interface, large display, and durable design, the Redmi A5 is ideal for seniors who are transitioning to their first smartphone.
Article Summary: Senior citizens seeking smartphones in 2026 can choose from multiple options that prioritise ease of use and accessibility. Whether you are looking for a smartphone with a large, easy-to-read display, loud and clear audio for better call quality, or extended battery life to reduce charging frequency, brands such as apple google and others offer a range of options.
